III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The facility is located on a residential street in an urban setting close to downtown
Kalamazoo. The facility is a three-story historical home with a large porch in the front of
the facility. Upon entry into the home (facility), there is a small foyer followed by a
second door leading to a larger foyer. To the left is the living room area there is a large
dining room. The dining table is large enough to have the 12-youth seated at once.
Upon entering the dining room, to the right is the front stairway followed by the office
just to the left of the stairway. Directly across the entrance from the living room is the
entrance to the kitchen. The kitchen is large and rectangle in shape. To the right of the
entry is the refrigerator, stove, counter tops and cupboards. To the left is a large
bedroom set up for one resident. Further into the kitchen is a second bedroom on the
left set up for two residents. Across from this second bedroom and on the outer wall is a
doorway leading to the side of the facility. At the end of the kitchen is a hallway that has
a three-quarter bathroom on the right. At the end of the hallway is a utility room that the
residents will not have access to. Across the hallway from the bathroom is the back
stairway to the second floor. At the top of the stairway to the right is a large bedroom set
up for two residents. Turning to the left the small hallway ends at a hallway that runs
perpendicular to the smaller hallway. To the left is a room that is used as a multiple use
room, “used for tutoring, visitation, or a de-escalation area”, for residents. Inside this
room is another door leading to a utility room that is not to be accessed by residents.
Coming back out of the multiple use room to the right is the third-floor stairway that is for
staff only. To the left is another full bathroom. Further down the hall to the right is
another bedroom set up for two residents with a bedroom across the hall that is also set
up for two residents. Another bedroom set up for two residents is further down the
hallway to the right and at the end of the hallway is a bedroom set up for a single
resident. The hallway turns to the left then right before connecting to the front stairway.
Each of the bedrooms observed had more than enough square footage space than
3

required and each bedroom had closets. All of the room had storage set up for
residents. There are cameras throughout the facility with the exception of the bedrooms
and bathrooms. The interior and exterior were well maintained. There is a driveway that
wraps around the facility and there are parking spaces in the back. Currently there is
construction of a fire escape for the staff area on the third floor being built on the back
side of the facility
B. Program Description
Let’s Talk About It Girls’ Home III is a community based residential program located in
Kalamazoo with a mission statement of “Empowering and equipping youth for success
beyond foster care”. The program will serve 12 female youth between the ages of 13
and 18 who have experienced abuse/neglect and struggled with mental/emotional
stability. These struggles can involve a need to develop skills for independent living,
substance abuse history, minimal behavioral issues (minimal aggression), difficulty in
establishing healthy relationships, and a history of abuse/neglect. The program will
provide an average length of stay between six and nine months with general outcome
goals of family reunification, entrance into independent living or adoption, if applicable.
The program will also focus on helping the youth develop the additional outcomes:
 Emotionally stability
 Independent living skills
 Understanding of the trauma in their lives and methods to cope with it
 Connection to community health (physical and mental) support systems
The program will provide a variety of treatment services starting with Psychiatric
consultations and evaluations within seven days of admission. Weekly trauma informed
individual, family and group therapy sessions. The therapy sessions will follow what is
outlined in the youth’s treatment plan along with self-help groups and family activities as
outlined in the treatment plan. Educational services will be provided to support the
youth’s educational efforts and each youth will be enrolled in a local school program.
This will involve tutoring if necessary, advocacy at IEP meetings and coordination with
all meetings at the youth’s school. Part of the independent living skills training will
involve a substance abuse assessment and education, health education (hygiene and
sexual choices) and education on the different aspects of self-esteem and healthy
relationships. The program is designed to address other issues as they are identified in
the assessment/evaluation process and outlined in the youth’s treatment plan. The
youth’s required activities are those activities that support the treatment goals and help
to build positive skills within the youth.
The intake/assessment process for youth involves the Psychiatric consultation and
evaluations within seven days of admission. The facility will use three assessment tools
(Adverse Childhood Experience [ACE], Biopsychosocial, Resilience and Casey Ansley)
to ensure that the identified problems bringing the youth into care are addressed in the
treatment goal development. Referrals will be received from the Department of Health
4

and Human Services, private child placing agencies and courts. If the youth meets the
admission criteria, (between the age of 13-18, have a IQ of 75 or above, exhibit minimal
aggressive behaviors, have a low AWLOP risk, no history of fire starting, and no active
substance use) the admission team will schedule an interview with the youth to further
determine if admission is appropriate. Once a determination is made for acceptance,
the facility will notify the referring worker within two business days. Factors considered
for room assignments will involve age, history of sexual acting out, and developmental
level.
Treatment goals will be developed through presenting problems (circumstances that
brought the youth into care) identified through the intake process, clinical assessments
(if identified as needed), information provided by the referring worker and youth’s
parents/caregiver, and a review of past assessments. The individualized treatment plan
developed will be agreed upon by the youth and they will receive a copy of the plan.
The youth and parents/caregivers will both be involved in the different goals and skill
building techniques in an effort to help the parents/caregivers understand positive and
healthy ways of being a support for the child. Progress of the plan will be evaluated
during weekly team meetings and in individual therapy sessions between the therapist
and youth.
The treatment program will utilize the Trauma Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
(TFCBT) modality. This modality has a focus on “addressing the multiple domains of
trauma impact including but not limited to Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD),
depression, anxiety, externalizing behavior problems, relationship and attachment
problems, school problems and cognitive problems. TFCBT includes skills for regulating
affect, behavior, thoughts and relationships, trauma processing, and enhancing safety,
trust, parenting skills and family communication”.
Let’s Talk About It Girls’ Home III treatment team consists of highly trained
professionals with skills in treatment plan development, de-escalation techniques, crisis
intervention, and skills development for the youth. Staffing consists of Licensed Master
level clinicians, Social Workers and Youth Services Specialists. Each of the treatment
staff are required to attend significant training on different interventions and methods of
positive interventions. The staff will be provided training in de-escalation techniques,
non-physical intervention methods and physical intervention techniques. Oversight to
the levels of staff is provided, and team meetings support a strong team approach to
providing services to the youth. Each youth’s progress will be evaluation during the
weekly team meetings with staff’s input. Staff is supervised by the administrative team
on all three shifts and the administrative team provides schedules, direction, and
support by telephone or in person. The administrative team will randomly review video
records to ensure that staff are following though appropriately in their interactions with
the residents.
Additional services and supervision involve the following: Staff with provide direct
supervision for residents as outlined in the contract and licensing rules. Supervision of
residents will also be determined by the needs of the residents. Youth in the program
5

will receive meals and snacks based on their nutritional needs. They will be provided
medical care which involves an initial medical physical and dental examination. They
will be provided updated immunizations and any necessary emergency medical care. If
a resident is on a regiment of medication, this will continue as prescribed and all
medication will be closely monitored and documented. A medication review will occur
every one to three months as needed. The facility describes further additional services:
We provide hands on independent living skills training, service plans/
treatment planning, group counseling, individual counseling, family
counseling, psychotropic medication management/ education, crisis
intervention, development of discharge plans, aftercare, family team
meeting, coordination of medical treatment, mentoring, community
activities, community referrals/ collaboration with community agencies,
coordination of employment in the community, coordination of drivers
training in the community, assessments to identify changing needs of
youth. Activities are scheduled daily for the youth in the home and in the
community (i.e. movies, skating, banking, apartment searching, budgeting,
YMCA, Urban Zone Community Center, WMU activities, how to access
community resources/ location and instruction, community service,
employment searching, use of the public transit system, and price
comparisons/ local stores).
Behavior management consists of staff using verbal de-escalation techniques. They will
use the following seven techniques while attempting to avoid physical intervention:
 Calm yourself before interaction with the person
 Becoming aware of your situation is also critically important.
 Try to look as non-threatening as possible
 Make a personal connection.
 Listening to the persons concerns.
 Shift the conversation to the future.
 Get them to say yes.
Staff are trained in the Safety-Care curriculum for behavior management that might
involve physical intervention. This involves a focus on prevention and de-escalation of
behavioral incident prior to any physical intervention. Staff are trained to provide
powerful, non-coercive ways to prevent crises and teach desirable, functional alternative
to dangerous and disruptive behavior. Some of the principles with this technique are
respect, dignity, avoidance of coercion, and the use of the least restrictive interventions
that are safe and effective. Each staff member will be fully trained in the Safety-Care
behavior management techniques prior to any physical intervention with a resident.
Discharge from the program will occur when a youth meets the criteria outlined in their
treatment plan. Planning for discharge will begin at the time of the intake. Discharge
planning will involve the treatment team, referral source and the youth with a focus on
appropriate aftercare planning. The program will provide aftercare follow up to ensure
the youth is successful in their aftercare.
6

C. Rule/Statutory Violations
There were no Rule violations found.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend issuance of a provisional license to this child caring institution,
private.
